issue.title: Disable Default CPU Limits for Istio Proxy-Version 1.11.3

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

Removing the CPU limits for the istio sidecar is not working and adds the default CPU limit of **2000m** to the sidecar. The default is causing the cluster to go into the overcommitted state, when the CPU limits are enforced based on the usage trend it's resulting in CPU throttling causing performance issues. Tried setting the limits value to “**null”** but it did not change the behavior. Setup is using the operator `apiVersion: install.istio.io/v1alpha1
kind: IstioOperator` and the CPU/memory values are updated under the global config as shown in the below snippet

```

`      proxy:
         resources:
          limits:
            memory: 150Mi
          requests:
            cpu: 20m
            memory: 150Mi
        statusPort: 15020
        tracer: zipkin
       proxy_init:
        image: proxyv2
        resources:
          limits:
            memory: 150Mi
          requests:
            cpu: 20m
            memory: 150Mi`

```


### Version

```prose
client version: 1.11.3
control-plane version: 1.11.3
data plane version: 1.11.3 (64 proxies)
```


### Additional Information

Output for >k get po sample-schema-producer -o yaml ; shows the default limit of 2 CPU enforced on the container

```
`    image: docker.io/istio/proxyv2:1.11.3
     imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
     name: istio-proxy
     ports:
     - containerPort: 15090
        name: http-envoy-prom
        protocol: TCP
     readinessProbe:
       failureThreshold: 30
       httpGet:
        path: /healthz/ready
        port: 15021
        scheme: HTTP
     initialDelaySeconds: 20
      periodSeconds: 5
      successThreshold: 1
      timeoutSeconds: 3
    resources:
      limits:
        cpu: "2"
        memory: 150Mi
      requests:
        cpu: 20m
        memory: 150Mi`
```

issue.title: Revise istioctl global flags displaying in options, and organize flag sets

labels.name: needs-rebase
labels.description: Indicates a PR needs to be rebased before being merged

labels.name: size/XXL
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
**Please provide a description of this PR:**
Originally https://github.com/istio/istio/issues/37938 was resolved in https://github.com/istio/istio/pull/38236. However it broke all `--help` commands, see https://github.com/istio/istio/pull/38236#pullrequestreview-1106554433. This PR addresses the problem, and organizes all the flags of a command in a new `Options` section like `kubectl`. For example:
```
istioctl admin log -h
Retrieve or update logging levels of istiod components.

Aliases:
log, l

Examples:
  # Retrieve information about istiod logging levels.
  istioctl admin log

  # Retrieve information about istiod logging levels on a specific control plane pod.
  istioctl admin l istiod-5c868d8bdd-pmvgg

  # Update levels of the specified loggers.
  istioctl admin log --level ads:debug,authorization:debug

  # Reset levels of all the loggers to default value (info).
  istioctl admin log -r

Options:
    --ctrlz_port=9876:
        ControlZ port

    --level='':
        Comma-separated list of output logging level for scopes in format
        <scope>:<level>[,<scope>:<level>,...]Possible values for <level>: none, error, warn, info, debug

    -o, --output='short':
        Output format: one of json|short

    -r, --reset=false:
        Reset levels to default value. (info)

    -l, --selector='app=istiod':
        label selector

    --stack-trace-level='':
        Comma-separated list of stack trace level  for scopes in format
        <scope>:<stack-trace-level>[,<scope>:<stack-trace-level>,...] Possible values for <stack-trace-level>: none,
        error, warn, info, debug

Usage:
  istioctl admin log [<pod-name>] [--level <scope>:<level>][--stack-trace-level
<scope>:<level>]|[-r|--reset]|[--output|-o short|yaml] [options]

Use "istioctl options" for a list of global command-line options (applies to all commands).

```

issue.title: istio-proxy intercepts traffic for local pod (hairpin connection) traffic regardless of includeInboundPorts and includeOutboundIPRanges

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

We are running prometheus and istio on k8s.  We have setup the integration between the two as per https://istio.io/latest/docs/ops/integrations/prometheus/ (option 2).  However for traffic from a prometheus pod to itself (ie prometheus monitoring itself) istio-proxy intercepts the traffic and drops it.  This means the usual service discovery scrape endpoint that is discovered can't be used.

* Pod annotations of include/exclude
    traffic.sidecar.istio.io/excludeInboundPorts: "15020"
    traffic.sidecar.istio.io/excludeOutboundIPRanges: 169.254.169.254/32
    traffic.sidecar.istio.io/includeInboundPorts: ""
    traffic.sidecar.istio.io/includeOutboundIPRanges: ""

* Pod ip is 10.17.97.7

* Attempt to connect to 10.17.97.7 on port 9090 to query metrics
$ kubectl -n monitoring exec -it prometheus-k8s-0 -c prometheus /bin/sh

/prometheus $ ip a
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
3: eth0@if23: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP,M-DOWN> mtu 9001 qdisc noqueue 
    link/ether 46:ef:f8:e5:3c:d0 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet 10.17.97.7/32 scope global eth0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever

/prometheus $ telnet 10.17.97.7 9090
Connected to 10.17.97.7
GET /metrics HTTP/1.0
Connection closed by foreign host

* istio-proxy logs

issue.title: sidecar config with workload selector is not applied to root namespace

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I am trying to setup the mTLS termination at sidecar using the sidecar API use case according to the newly introduced feature in istio 1.13 based on https://github.com/istio/istio/pull/36210  and came around the following limitation:

When installing the example mentioned [here](https://github.com/istio/api/blob/master/networking/v1alpha3/sidecar.proto#L404) in `istio-system` namespace(instead of prod-us1 namespace as in the example), which is the default rootNamespace in my deployment, the workload selector in the sidecar configuration doesn’t become effective. This seems to be due to the specific behaviour of the sidecar API in rootNamespace, see Note 2 on https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/config/networking/sidecar/

[Note2](https://github.com/istio/api/blob/master/networking/v1alpha3/sidecar.proto#L57)

This means in the end, the entire use case becomes ‘invalid’ for the rootNamespace.
Is this limitation of sidecar API intentional? This makes the TLS termination at sidecar solution unusable for us.

The below code seems to be the relevant area which checks if rootNamespace sidecar config has a workloadSelector or not:
https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/master/pilot/pkg/model/push_context.go#L1637

### Version

```prose
istioctl version : 1.14.1
kubectl version: 1.23.1
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

This means in the end, the entire use case becomes ‘invalid’ for the rootNamespace.
Is this limitation of sidecar API intentional? This makes the TLS termination at sidecar solution unusable for us.

The below code seems to be the relevant area which checks if rootNamespace sidecar config has a workloadSelector or not:
https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/master/pilot/pkg/model/push_context.go#L1637

### Version

```prose
istioctl version : 1.14.1
kubectl version: 1.23.1
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: HTTPFaultInjection in VS does not work if percentage is omitted

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

## Description
I was trying to configure HTTPFaultInjection in my VirtualService and as per [documentation](https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/config/networking/virtual-service/#HTTPFaultInjection-Abort), the `percentage` field is optional. Omitting it should `abort` all the requests meeting the criteria. 

But when I omit it, the `abort` faultInjection stops working and all the requests pass through to the upstream cluster successfully. I'm unsure if this is a bug in the implementation or if I'm using it incorrectly?

## Steps to reproduce
1. Install the httpbin app in a mesh enabled NS
2. Install the sleep app in a mesh enabled NS
3. Create a VS as shown below
```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: sleep-vs
spec:
  hosts:
  - httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local
  http:
  - fault:
      abort:
        httpStatus: 403
    route:
    - destination:
        host: httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local
        port: 
          number: 8000
    match:
      - uri:
          prefix: "/get"
```
4. Try to make a request from the sleep pod
```
k exec <SLEEP_POD> -it -- curl -vso /dev/null http://httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local:8000/get
``` 

## Expectation
The expectation was that all the requests to the `/get` endpoint should result in `403`. 

## What was observed?
All the requests returned `200`.

Please do let me know if I'm missing something

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.2
control plane version: 1.13.2
data plane version: 1.13.2 (4 proxies)

$  k version --short
Client Version: v1.21.2
Server Version: v1.22.1
```


### Additional Information

Here is the corresponding envoy config snippet
```json
"name": "httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local:8000",
"domains": [
	"httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local",
	"httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local:8000",
	"httpbin",
	"httpbin:8000",
	"httpbin.default.svc",
	"httpbin.default.svc:8000",
	"httpbin.default",
	"httpbin.default:8000",
],
"routes": [{
		"match": {
			"prefix": "/get",
			"case_sensitive": true
		},
		"route": {
			"cluster": "outbound|8000||httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local",
			"timeout": "0s",
			"retry_policy": {
				"retry_on": "connect-failure,refused-stream,unavailable,cancelled,retriable-status-codes",
				"num_retries": 2,
				"retry_host_predicate": [{
					"name": "envoy.retry_host_predicates.previous_hosts"
				}],
				"host_selection_retry_max_attempts": "5",
				"retriable_status_codes": [
					503
				]
			},
			"max_grpc_timeout": "0s"
		},
		"metadata": {
			"filter_metadata": {
				"istio": {
					"config": "/apis/networking.istio.io/v1alpha3/namespaces/default/virtual-service/sleep-vs"
				}
			}
		},
		"decorator": {
			"operation": "httpbin.default.svc.cluster.local:8000/get*"
		},
		"typed_per_filter_config": {
			"envoy.filters.http.fault": {
				"@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.fault.v3.HTTPFault",
				"abort": {
					"http_status": 403
				}
			}
		}
	}
```

issue.title: Intermittent Http1.codec in sidecar  when envoy lua filter enabled
issue.body:
### Bug Description

Deployment
Ingress+istio SIdecar (with lua filter attached to outbound). --> Sidecar Inbound+ µservice

In lua filter
Read bodyChunks to avoid https://github.com/envoyproxy/envoy/issues/16674
Make synchronous call suing httpCall API
Allow the request if API response is OK.

Under stress 1 %  Post request with body  rejected with 400 bad request cause:- http1.codec_error at Inbound sidecar of µService.
If we remove LUA filter or remove bodyChunks call issue is not seen.

### Version

```prose
bash-4.2$ istioctl version
client version: 1.12.1
control plane version: 1.12.1
data plane version: 1.12.1 (1567 proxies)
bash-4.2$ 
bash-4.2$ 
bash-4.2$ 
bash-4.2$ kubectl  version --short
Client Version: v1.17.0
Server Version: v1.20.8
bash-4.2$
```


### Additional Information

SIDECAR_OUTBOUND

sample lua filter
```
 match:
        context: SIDECAR_OUTBOUND
      patch:
        operation: INSERT_BEFORE
        value:
          name: envoy.lua
          typed_config:
            '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.lua.v3.Lua
            inlineCode: |
              function envoy_on_request(request_handle)
                local p = request_handle:headers():get(":path")
                local rlHeaders = {}
                local sid = request_handle:headers():get("someheader")
                local ridOr = request_handle:headers():get("someHedaer")
                local rid = string.gsub(ridOr, "/", "%%2F")
                local rlkey = sid .. "/" .. rid
                local len = 0
               -- below seems to be causing this.
                for chunk in request_handle:bodyChunks() do
                    len = len + chunk:length()
                end
                rlHeaders[":method"] = "PUT"
                rlHeaders[":path"] = "/someURL/" .. rlkey
                rlHeaders[":authority"] = "cluster.svc.cluster.local"
                local headers, body = request_handle:httpCall(
                 "lua_cluster",
                rlHeaders,
                nil, 
                5000)
             end
```

labels.name: feature/Virtual-machine

issue.body:
### Bug Description

I am trying to achieve this scenario:

- From an application within the mesh I connect to this host: "external-mq" and port: 1414
- "external-mq" is a Service Entry that should register in the mesh the service located here: "dev-mq.mycompany.corp"

This is my solution, but it's not working:
```yml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: external-mq
  labels:
    app: external-mq
spec:
  hosts:
    - dev-mq.mycompany.corp
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  ports:
  - number: 1414
    name: tcp-mq
    protocol: TCP
  resolution: DNS
---
# I am using a Virtual Service to redirect traffic from the host "external-mq" to host "dev-mq.mycompany.corp"
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: external-mq-service
spec:
  hosts:
  - external-mq
  http:
  - match:
    - port: 1414
    route:
    - destination:
        host: dev-mq.mycompany.corp
        port:
          number: 1414
```
The external service that I am trying to use is an IBM MQ instance.
It's exposed at this DNS: dev-mq.mycompany.corp and port: 1414.

If inside my application (that runs inside the mesh) I use the DNS, it works to connect to the service, but as I said I want to use the host: "external-mq" not the DNS.
My end goal is to setup network resilience features (reties, timeouts, etc) on top of the Service Entry "external-mq".

I tried to follow Istio's documentation to setup a ServiceEntry but either the documentation is poor, either I am a muggle.. Maybe both..

We see an unexpected behavior with one of our Go-based services, it is calling another service 2x times without any retry logic in the application. On further debugging, we found ISTIO has default retried 2 times on Virtual Service. We tried to disable it by adding retries: attempts: 0 to virtual service but this value is not set to 0. Could you please advice on what could be wrong here. Below is the virtual service being used. Thanks

```

metadata:

issue.title: Locality based routing not working for istio-proxy to istio-egressgateway traffic...

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

When our traffic routes out from an `istio-proxy` sidecar through an `istio-egressgateway` pod, we want the traffic to stay within-zone whenever possible so that we can avoid paying cross-AZ network costs. For setting up the EgressGateways, we followed the docs at https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/traffic-management/egress/egress-gateway/ (with a minor change, I'll describe it in the "Additional Information" section below).

We have other high volume services within the mesh that use locality-aware routing to great success, so we do understand that it works fundamentally within the mesh. I can confirm that it works when we route traffic _from_ an `istio-ingressgateway` _to_ a pod with an `istio-proxy` sidecar. It just doesn't seem to work in the reverse flow out of an egressgateway.

I've posted on Slack (https://istio.slack.com/archives/C37A4KAAD/p1657034565248319, https://istio.slack.com/archives/C37A4KAAD/p1656698370327109) and also dug through the `discuss.istio.io` page for help on this but I haven't found the answer yet.

My concern here is that this may simply not be a supported thing to do - or if it is, there must be something in the documentation we're missing or not understanding..

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.3
control plane version: 1.14.0
data plane version: 1.14.0 (19 proxies)
```

```
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.23.5
Server Version: v1.22.9-eks-a64ea69
```
```


### Additional Information

Other than a fairly standard Istio installation, here are the resources we've configured to try to make the egress routing work. We followed the docs at https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/traffic-management/egress/egress-gateway/ pretty closely, however we made one change to reconfigure plaintext HTTP traffic (`http://httpbin.org`) to go out to the target destination via HTTPS:

## `Gateway: istio-egressgateway`
```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  generation: 3
  name: istio-egressgateway
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  selector:
    istio: egressgateway
  servers:
  - hosts:
    - '*'
    port:
      name: http
      number: 80
      protocol: HTTP
  - hosts:
    - '*'
    port:
      name: tls
      number: 443
      protocol: TLS
    tls:
      mode: PASSTHROUGH
```

## `DestinationRule: istio-egressgateway`

We created a `DestinationRule` for the egressgateway itself (traffic from the mesh -> gateway) to try to control the outlier detection:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: istio-egressgateway
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
  trafficPolicy:
    connectionPool:
      http:
        maxRequestsPerConnection: 100
    outlierDetection:
      baseEjectionTime: 30s
      consecutiveGatewayErrors: 7
      interval: 10s
```

## `ServiceEntry: httpbin-org`
```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  generation: 1
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  hosts:
  - httpbin.org
  ports:
  - name: http
    number: 80
    protocol: HTTP
    targetPort: 443
  - name: tls
    number: 443
    protocol: TLS
  resolution: DNS
```

## `DestinationRule: httpbin-org`

This `DestinationRule` is used to reconfigure traffic targeting port 80 to re-route to port 443... it should only apply on the egressgateway where the final traffic out to the real destination is happening:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  host: httpbin.org
  trafficPolicy:
    portLevelSettings:
    - port:
        number: 80
      tls:
        mode: SIMPLE
```

## `VirtualService: httpbin-org`

Finally here's the `VirtualService`:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  gateways:
  - istio-egressgateway
  - mesh
  hosts:
  - httpbin.org
  http:
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      port: 80
    route:
    - destination:
        host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 80
      weight: 100
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - istio-egressgateway
      port: 80
    route:
    - destination:
        host: httpbin.org
        port:
          number: 80
      weight: 100
  tls:
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      port: 443
      sniHosts:
      - httpbin.org
    route:
    - destination:
        host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 443
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - istio-egressgateway
      port: 443
      sniHosts:
      - httpbin.org
    route:
    - destination:

issue.title: Locality based routing not working for istio-proxy to istio-egressgateway traffic...

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

When our traffic routes out from an `istio-proxy` sidecar through an `istio-egressgateway` pod, we want the traffic to stay within-zone whenever possible so that we can avoid paying cross-AZ network costs. For setting up the EgressGateways, we followed the docs at https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/traffic-management/egress/egress-gateway/ (with a minor change, I'll describe it in the "Additional Information" section below).

We have other high volume services within the mesh that use locality-aware routing to great success, so we do understand that it works fundamentally within the mesh. I can confirm that it works when we route traffic _from_ an `istio-ingressgateway` _to_ a pod with an `istio-proxy` sidecar. It just doesn't seem to work in the reverse flow out of an egressgateway.

I've posted on Slack (https://istio.slack.com/archives/C37A4KAAD/p1657034565248319, https://istio.slack.com/archives/C37A4KAAD/p1656698370327109) and also dug through the `discuss.istio.io` page for help on this but I haven't found the answer yet.

My concern here is that this may simply not be a supported thing to do - or if it is, there must be something in the documentation we're missing or not understanding..

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.13.3
control plane version: 1.14.0
data plane version: 1.14.0 (19 proxies)
```

```
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.23.5
Server Version: v1.22.9-eks-a64ea69
```
```


### Additional Information

Other than a fairly standard Istio installation, here are the resources we've configured to try to make the egress routing work. We followed the docs at https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/traffic-management/egress/egress-gateway/ pretty closely, however we made one change to reconfigure plaintext HTTP traffic (`http://httpbin.org`) to go out to the target destination via HTTPS:

## `Gateway: istio-egressgateway`
```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  generation: 3
  name: istio-egressgateway
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  selector:
    istio: egressgateway
  servers:
  - hosts:
    - '*'
    port:
      name: http
      number: 80
      protocol: HTTP
  - hosts:
    - '*'
    port:
      name: tls
      number: 443
      protocol: TLS
    tls:
      mode: PASSTHROUGH
```

## `DestinationRule: istio-egressgateway`

We created a `DestinationRule` for the egressgateway itself (traffic from the mesh -> gateway) to try to control the outlier detection:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: istio-egressgateway
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
  trafficPolicy:
    connectionPool:
      http:
        maxRequestsPerConnection: 100
    outlierDetection:
      baseEjectionTime: 30s
      consecutiveGatewayErrors: 7
      interval: 10s
```

## `ServiceEntry: httpbin-org`
```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  generation: 1
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  hosts:
  - httpbin.org
  ports:
  - name: http
    number: 80
    protocol: HTTP
    targetPort: 443
  - name: tls
    number: 443
    protocol: TLS
  resolution: DNS
```

## `DestinationRule: httpbin-org`

This `DestinationRule` is used to reconfigure traffic targeting port 80 to re-route to port 443... it should only apply on the egressgateway where the final traffic out to the real destination is happening:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: DestinationRule
metadata:
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  host: httpbin.org
  trafficPolicy:
    portLevelSettings:
    - port:
        number: 80
      tls:
        mode: SIMPLE
```

## `VirtualService: httpbin-org`

Finally here's the `VirtualService`:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: httpbin-org
  namespace: istio-system
spec:
  gateways:
  - istio-egressgateway
  - mesh
  hosts:
  - httpbin.org
  http:
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      port: 80
    route:
    - destination:
        host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 80
      weight: 100
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - istio-egressgateway
      port: 80
    route:
    - destination:
        host: httpbin.org
        port:
          number: 80
      weight: 100
  tls:
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      port: 443
      sniHosts:
      - httpbin.org
    route:
    - destination:
        host: istio-egressgateway.istio-system.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 443
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - istio-egressgateway
      port: 443
      sniHosts:
      - httpbin.org
    route:
    - destination:
        host: httpbin.org
        port:
          number: 443
      weight: 100
```

## Logs from Requests

Ok, with this in mind, I launched a debug pod with an `istio-proxy` sidecar and I start curl'ling `httpbin.org/ip` and we can see that the `upstream_host` is fairly randomly selected:

```
$ k -n matt-test logs debug-diranged-8584a8da -c istio-proxy | grep httpbin | grep upstream | jq .upstream_host
"10.32.29.129:8080"
"10.32.28.194:8080"
"10.32.28.194:8080"
"10.32.28.83:8080"
"10.32.28.194:8080"
"10.32.29.129:8080"
"10.32.28.194:8080"
"10.32.29.129:8080"
"10.32.28.83:8080"
"10.32.29.129:8080"
"10.32.29.129:8080"

```

The logs on the `istio-egressgateway` containers are spread out between the containers too:

issue.title: Envoy proxy is NOT ready: config received from XDS server, but was rejected

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
Guys we need some help to investigate this problem in our production clusters.

In our environments we are experiencing a weird issue with the latest 1.14.1 version.
Before we use the last 1.13 version.
The problem occurs in some environment and it is not systematically reproducible. 

The problem is the following:
after the upgrade to the 1.14.1 version, we did a restart of the deployments we have in the cluster and we saw many errors like `Envoy proxy is NOT ready: config received from XDS server, but was rejected: cds updates: 0 successful, 13 rejected; lds updates: 13 successful, 0 rejected` on the new pods logs.
This generated a problem since the pods were not ready and they were not able to communicate.

From the logs we saw
`Internal:Unable to unpack as envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster: type_url: "[type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster](http://type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster)"`
but the weird thing is that we have no envoy filters with the above type.
Indeed we did an istioctl analyze on all the namespaces without errors so our istio object components (envoy filter, destination rule and so on) seem to be ok.

Furthermore we saw:
```
2022-06-22T11:29:58.062649Z	warning	envoy config	Unknown field: type google.protobuf.Duration(envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster) with unknown field set {6}
2022-06-22T11:29:58.063383Z	warning	envoy config	gRPC config for type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster rejected: Proto constraint validation failed (ClusterValidationError.ConnectTimeout: value must be greater than 0s): name: "outbound|443||eu-fr2.mydomain.com"
```

This problem occurs in all our production clusters and we sporadically see the same error on the dev environments.

We have multiple envoyfilters attached to our microservices.
In particular we have:
- ms-a microservice
- ms-b microservice 
- ms-c microservice 
- ms-d microservice 
- ms-e microservice 

and we tried to remove all the envoy filters (this fixed the problem) before to reapply they one per one and the problem occurs randomly.
We tried:
- removing all the envoyfilters and reapplying one per one: this generates the problem sometimes (not always).
- removing only a subset of the envoyfilters and reapplying one per one: like above.
- removing one per one until we saw the problem was fixed. 
About the last one we saw this behavior in some clusters but the removed envoy filter were different between the clusters. For example, in one cluster we removed the `envoy-filter-ms-jsonlogformat` filter while in another one we removed the `connect_timeout` section but we have no evidences of which of the filters is the problem.

Do you have any idea on how to debug this weird problem?

To give you some context, we use the following envoy filters:
```
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: envoy-filter-ms-a
  namespace: ms
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      app: ms-a
  configPatches:
    - applyTo: CLUSTER
      match:
        context: ANY
      patch:
        operation: MERGE
        value:
          connect_timeout: 120s
    - applyTo: HTTP_FILTER
      match:
        context: SIDECAR_INBOUND
        listener:
          filterChain:
            filter:
              name: "envoy.filters.network.http_connection_manager"
      patch:
        operation: INSERT_BEFORE
        value:
          name: "envoy.filters.http.lua"
          typed_config:
            "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.lua.v3.Lua"
            inlineCode: |
              function envoy_on_request(request_handle)
                local body = request_handle:body()
                if body then
                  local body_size = body:length()
                  local one_megabyte_in_bytes = 1024 * 1024
                  local limit_in_mb = 5
                  if body_size > (limit_in_mb * one_megabyte_in_bytes) then
                    request_handle:respond({[":status"] = "413", ["error_envoy_filter"] = "Payload Too Large"}, "Payload Too Large")
                  end
                end
                request_handle:headers():remove("cookie")
              end
---
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: envoy-filter-ms-b
  namespace: ms
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      app: ms-b
  configPatches:
    - applyTo: CLUSTER
      match:
        context: ANY
      patch:
        operation: MERGE
        value:
          connect_timeout: 120s
    - applyTo: HTTP_FILTER
      match:
        context: SIDECAR_INBOUND
        listener:
          filterChain:
            filter:
              name: "envoy.filters.network.http_connection_manager"
      patch:
        operation: INSERT_BEFORE
        value:

            inlineCode: |

                    request_handle:respond({[":status"] = "413", ["error_envoy_filter"] = "Payload Too Large"}, "Payload Too Large")

            inlineCode: |

issue.title: Envoy proxy is NOT ready: config received from XDS server, but was rejected

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
Guys we need some help to investigate this problem in our production clusters.

In our environments we are experiencing a weird issue with the latest 1.14.1 version.
Before we use the last 1.13 version.
The problem occurs in some environment and it is not systematically reproducible. 

The problem is the following:
after the upgrade to the 1.14.1 version, we did a restart of the deployments we have in the cluster and we saw many errors like `Envoy proxy is NOT ready: config received from XDS server, but was rejected: cds updates: 0 successful, 13 rejected; lds updates: 13 successful, 0 rejected` on the new pods logs.
This generated a problem since the pods were not ready and they were not able to communicate.

From the logs we saw
`Internal:Unable to unpack as envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster: type_url: "[type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster](http://type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster)"`
but the weird thing is that we have no envoy filters with the above type.
Indeed we did an istioctl analyze on all the namespaces without errors so our istio object components (envoy filter, destination rule and so on) seem to be ok.

Furthermore we saw:
```
2022-06-22T11:29:58.062649Z	warning	envoy config	Unknown field: type google.protobuf.Duration(envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster) with unknown field set {6}
2022-06-22T11:29:58.063383Z	warning	envoy config	gRPC config for type.googleapis.com/envoy.config.cluster.v3.Cluster rejected: Proto constraint validation failed (ClusterValidationError.ConnectTimeout: value must be greater than 0s): name: "outbound|443||eu-fr2.mydomain.com"
```

This problem occurs in all our production clusters and we sporadically see the same error on the dev environments.

We have multiple envoyfilters attached to our microservices.
In particular we have:
- ms-a microservice
- ms-b microservice 
- ms-c microservice 
- ms-d microservice 
- ms-e microservice 

and we tried to remove all the envoy filters (this fixed the problem) before to reapply they one per one and the problem occurs randomly.
We tried:
- removing all the envoyfilters and reapplying one per one: this generates the problem sometimes (not always).
- removing only a subset of the envoyfilters and reapplying one per one: like above.
- removing one per one until we saw the problem was fixed. 
About the last one we saw this behavior in some clusters but the removed envoy filter were different between the clusters. For example, in one cluster we removed the `envoy-filter-ms-jsonlogformat` filter while in another one we removed the `connect_timeout` section but we have no evidences of which of the filters is the problem.

Do you have any idea on how to debug this weird problem?

To give you some context, we use the following envoy filters:
```

kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: envoy-filter-ms-a
  namespace: ms
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      app: ms-a
  configPatches:
    - applyTo: CLUSTER
      match:
        context: ANY
      patch:
        operation: MERGE
        value:
          connect_timeout: 120s
    - applyTo: HTTP_FILTER
      match:
        context: SIDECAR_INBOUND
        listener:
          filterChain:
            filter:
              name: "envoy.filters.network.http_connection_manager"
      patch:
        operation: INSERT_BEFORE
        value:
          name: "envoy.filters.http.lua"
          typed_config:
            "@type": "type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.lua.v3.Lua"
            inlineCode: |
              function envoy_on_request(request_handle)
                local body = request_handle:body()
                if body then
                  local body_size = body:length()
                  local one_megabyte_in_bytes = 1024 * 1024
                  local limit_in_mb = 5
                  if body_size > (limit_in_mb * one_megabyte_in_bytes) then
                    request_handle:respond({[":status"] = "413", ["error_envoy_filter"] = "Payload Too Large"}, "Payload Too Large")
                  end
                end
                request_handle:headers():remove("cookie")
              end
---

issue.title: Dangerous global variable usage in istioctl

labels.name: lifecycle/automatically-closed
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue that has been closed automatically.

issue.body:
Istioctl is full of global variables for things like kubeconfig, etc. This has caused a variety of issues in the past like:
* multiple calls to istioctl re-using the wrong variables between calls
* Parallel calls causing race conditions
* **connecting to users real clusters and performing mutation actions against their real cluster** in unit tests

As well as just generally being a bad practice.

We should refactor this a bit to follow best practices and avoid global mutable state.

issue.title: fix: excludes Ruby env vars
issue.body:
When using tools such as `rvm` host env variables contain e.g. `GEM_HOME` and `GEM_PATH`. These might differ with what is expected by the container. 

As a consequence running tests lead to errors such as

```
build-tools:/work$ fpm
/usr/lib/ruby/vendor_ruby/rubygems.rb:265:in `find_spec_for_exe': can't find gem fpm (>= 0.a) with executable fpm (Gem::GemNotFoundException)
	from /usr/lib/ruby/vendor_ruby/rubygems.rb:284:in `activate_bin_path'
	from /usr/local/bin/fpm:25:in `<main>'
```

This PR excludes `rvm`-related variables.

issue.body:
### Bug Description

We have configured multiple IP address for a FQDN. We are routing the request using FQDN. We are also expecing when one of the IP address goes down and then Istio will retry to another IP address which is not happening. The envoy filter which uses is given below. 
----
[root@asisvm ~]# nslookup nwsim.test.asis.org
Server:         10.75.196.177
Address:        10.75.196.177#53

Name:   nwsim.test.asis.org
Address: 10.75.145.7
Name:   nwsim.test.asis.org
Address: 10.143.118.244
;; Got recursion not available from 10.75.196.177, trying next server
** server can't find nwsim.test.asis.org: NXDOMAIN
-----------
envoy filter
---------------
````
spec:
  configPatches:
  - applyTo: LISTENER
    match:
      context: SIDECAR_OUTBOUND
    patch:
      operation: ADD
      value:
        address:
          socket_address:
            address: 0.0.0.0
            port_value: 10000
            protocol: TCP
        filter_chains:
        - filters:
          - name: envoy.http_connection_manager
            typed_config:
              '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.network.http_connection_manager.v3.HttpConnectionManager
              http_filters:
              - name: envoy.filters.http.dynamic_forward_proxy
                typed_config:
                  '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.dynamic_forward_proxy.v3.FilterConfig
                  dns_cache_config:
                    dns_lookup_family: V4_ONLY
                    name: dynamic_forward_proxy_cache_config
              - name: envoy.filters.http.lua
                typed_config:
                  '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.lua.v3.Lua
                  inline_code: |
                    function envoy_on_request(request_handle)
                      request_handle:logInfo("Hello World.")
                    end
              - name: envoy.router
                typed_config:
                  '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.router.v3.Router
              route_config:
                name: local_route
                request_headers_to_remove:
                - x-envoy-peer-metadata
                - x-envoy-peer-metadata-id
                virtual_hosts:
                - domains:
                  - https.traffic.domain
                  name: https_service
                  retry_policy:
                    host_selection_retry_max_attempts: 3
                    num_retries: 2
                    per_try_timeout: 3s
                    retry_host_predicate:
                    - name: envoy.retry_host_predicates.previous_hosts
                    retry_on: connect-failure,refused-stream,503
                  routes:
                  - match:
                      prefix: /
                    route:
                      cluster: https_dynamic_forward_proxy_cluster
                - domains:
                  - nwsim.*
                  - http.traffic.domain
                  name: http_service
                  retry_policy:
                    host_selection_retry_max_attempts: 3
                    num_retries: 2
                    per_try_timeout: 3s
                    retry_host_predicate:
                    - name: envoy.retry_host_predicates.previous_hosts
                    retry_on: connect-failure,refused-stream,503
                  routes:
                  - match:
                      prefix: /
                    route:
                      cluster: http_dynamic_forward_proxy_cluster
              stat_prefix: ingress_http
        name: proxy
  - applyTo: CLUSTER
    match:
      context: SIDECAR_OUTBOUND
    patch:
      operation: ADD
      value:
        cluster_type:
          name: envoy.clusters.dynamic_forward_proxy
          typed_config:
            '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.clusters.dynamic_forward_proxy.v3.ClusterConfig
            dns_cache_config:
              dns_lookup_family: V4_ONLY
              name: dynamic_forward_proxy_cache_config
        connect_timeout: 1s
        http2_protocol_options:
          max_concurrent_streams: 1073741824
        lb_policy: CLUSTER_PROVIDED
        name: https_dynamic_forward_proxy_cluster
        transport_socket:
          name: envoy.transport_sockets.tls
          typed_config:
            '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.transport_sockets.tls.v3.UpstreamTlsContext
            common_tls_context:
              alpn_protocols:
              - h2
              tls_certificates:
              - {}
              validation_context:
                match_typed_subject_alt_names:
                - san_type: DNS
  - applyTo: CLUSTER
    match:
      context: SIDECAR_OUTBOUND
    patch:
      operation: ADD
      value:
        cluster_type:
          name: envoy.clusters.dynamic_forward_proxy
          typed_config:
            '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.clusters.dynamic_forward_proxy.v3.ClusterConfig
            dns_cache_config:
              dns_lookup_family: V4_ONLY
              name: dynamic_forward_proxy_cache_config
        connect_timeout: 1s
        http2_protocol_options:
          max_concurrent_streams: 1073741824
        lb_policy: CLUSTER_PROVIDED
        name: http_dynamic_forward_proxy_cluster
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      app: test
```
-------------
Observation
------------------
1. Istio tries to send one IP address which is resolved and if that IP address goes down, in this case retry happen to same IP address (expectation is retry to other IP address),
2. Istio tries to send one IP address which is resolved and if that IP address goes down, after multipe fail attempt nearly 15-20 secs approximately, Istio send the request to another IP address (expectation is retry to alternate IP address in case route/connect to other IP address is failed)

### Version

```prose
Istio 1.7.6
$kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.14.3
Server Version: v1.19.7
$helm3 version --short
v3.2.4+g0ad800e
```

_No response_

issue.title: EnvoyFilter is not applied when rediness gate exists and health check failed in Istio
issue.body:
### Bug Description

We have an `EnvoyFilter` for route http request to upstream application port as below:

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: my-envoy-filter
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      app: my-app
  configPatches:
  - applyTo: ROUTE_CONFIGURATION
    match:
      context: SIDECAR_INBOUND
      routeConfiguration:
        portNumber: 80
        vhost:
          name: "inbound|http|80"
    patch:
      operation: MERGE
      value:
       name: local_route
       virtual_hosts:
        - name: local_service
          domains:
            - "*.myservice.com"
          routes:
            - match: { prefix: "/" }
              route:
                cluster: mycluster
                priority: HIGH
  - applyTo: CLUSTER
    match:
      context: SIDECAR_INBOUND
    patch:
      operation: ADD
      value:
        name: mycluster
        type: LOGICAL_DNS
        connect_timeout: 0.25s
        lb_policy: ROUND_ROBIN
        load_assignment:
          cluster_name: mycluster
          endpoints:
            - lb_endpoints:
              - endpoint:
                  address:
                    socket_address:
                      address: 127.0.0.1
                      port_value: 9999
```

It works properly when I applied it to workloads which doesn't have any rediness gate property (for associated AWS target group).

However, if a workload has its own rediness gate and the **rediness check faile**d, then the **EnvoyFilter doesn't seem to be applied** properly.

Is it an intended result? 
Are the proxy configurations are applied after the rediness gate confirmed the health of the proxy?
Is there anyway to apply proxy configurations such as EnvoyFilter before the rediness gate confirmation?

### Version

```prose
% istioctl version
client version: 1.13.2
control plane version: 1.13.2
data plane version: 1.13.2 (237 proxies)

% kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.22.3
Server Version: v1.20.4
WARNING: version difference between client (1.22) and server (1.20) exceeds the supported minor version skew of +/-1
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: Problem with Service with MetalLB loadbalancerIP

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

Hello all,

I am sorry for the format, I started by trying to open a discussion on _[discuss.istio.io](discuss.istio.io)_, but the site seems to be abandonned but by pill manufacturers.


We activated istio in our lab in PERMISSIVE mode and a few services broke.  One of them is a loadbalancer for mariadb servers that live outside of kubernetes.  The loadbalancers live in pods and the service fronting them is using a LoadbalancerIP obtained through MetalLB.  


In schema that follow, the Mariadb servers live in vms.  Before injection with with the side car, everything worked just fine.  Connexion path 1,2, 3 and 4 worked juste fine.


Once side-car injection has happened, a few connexions stoped working.
![With Istio](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1424864/180006259-bd5784ec-d6c8-4bf1-84c4-e9c60ec3cc53.png)


That is, connexion 1 and 3 that try to talk to the LoadBalancerIP (which is obviously not a clusterIP) do not work.  It obviously has to do with the server [side protocol](https://istio.io/latest/docs/ops/deployment/requirements/#server-first-protocols) that is mysql.  I have modified the service in the `infra-lb` namespace to tag correctly the service with either or both `appProtocol` field or to make sure the name respects `name: <protocol>[-<suffix>]` syntax.

To no avail.  The behaviour is still different between the two IPs.  By the ways, CentOS-tools is simply a centos image with lots of tools that we have in each of our kubernetes clusters so we can comfortably tests things.

Notice that the CentOS-tools pod can talk directly to mariadb through connexion without any issues.

I can fix the problem for the CentOS tools image which belong to the mesh by publishing a ServiceEntry and VirtualService (in infra-lb)  for the LoadBlancerIP.  Yes, not for the mariadb Server, but for the service.

```yaml
piVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio
spec:
  hosts:
  - mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio.interne.lab.montreal.ca # not used
  addresses:
  - 10.224.3.102 # LoadBlancer VIPs obtained through MetallLB
  ports:
  - number: 3306
    #name: tcp-maria
    name: maria
    protocol: TCP
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  resolution: NONE
 ``` 

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: routetcp-maria-mettallb
spec:
  hosts:
  - mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio.interne.lab.montreal.ca
  tcp:
  - match:
    - port: 3306
    route:
    - destination:
        host: haproxy-mariadb-srv
        port:
          number: 3306
```

This will correct connexion 3.  That is, the centOS pod that belongs to the mesh will now be able to connect to mariadb using the LoadBalancerIP.  But, external connexion still do not work, connexion one for instance.

I have being able to make it work by adding a PeerAuthentication object that deactivates mTLS  altogether :

```yaml
apiVersion: security.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: PeerAuthentication
metadata:
  name: default
spec:
  mtls:
    mode: DISABLE
  # portLevelMtls:
  #   3306:
  #     mode: DISABLE
```

Notice that I cannot have `mtls` to `PERMISSIVE` and `portLevelMtls` to `DISABLE`.  It's just ignored for some reason.

Can anyone shed light on this behaviour ?  Why are there differences for cluster-ip and loadbalancer ip when coming in from the mesh.  And differences between mesh clients and outside-of-kubernetes clients on the loadbalancer-ip ?  Is it possible to have my cake and eat it too ?  That is have mTLS for mesh clients and no TLS for external clients ?  Finally, why the weird behaviour of the PeerAuthentication.

From my perspective, there should be no difference where from I enter the service on through which IP I connect to the service.


Note that the problem was there in 1.13.x and is still there in 1.14.y

### Version

```prose
istioctl version 
client version: 1.14.1
istiod version: 1.13.2
istiod version: 1.13.2
istiod version: 1.14.1
istiod version: 1.14.1
data plane version: 1.14.1 (9 proxies), 1.13.2 (83 proxies)



kubectl version --short      
Flag --short has been deprecated, and will be removed in the future. The --short output will become the default.
Client Version: v1.24.2
Kustomize Version: v4.5.4
Server Version: v1.21.5


helm version --short
v3.9.0+g7ceeda6
```


### Additional Information

istioctl bug-report

Target cluster context: simon pierre@lab

Running with the following config: 

istio-namespace: istio-system
full-secrets: false
timeout (mins): 30
include: {  }
exclude: { Namespaces: kube-node-lease,kube-public,kube-system,local-path-storage }
end-time: 2022-07-20 10:28:32.843429 -0400 EDT



Cluster endpoint: https://masters.kube-vert.lab.ile.montreal.qc.ca:6443
CLI version:
version.BuildInfo{Version:"1.14.1", GitRevision:"f59ce19ec6b63bbb70a65c43ac423845f1129464-dirty", GolangVersion:"go1.18.3", BuildStatus:"Clean", GitTag:"1.14.1"}

The following Istio control plane revisions/versions were found in the cluster:
Revision 1-13-2:
&version.MeshInfo{
    {
        Component: "istiod",
        Info:      version.BuildInfo{Version:"1.13.2", GitRevision:"91533d04e894ff86b80acd6d7a4517b144f9e19a", GolangVersion:"", BuildStatus:"Clean", GitTag:"1.13.2"},
    },
    {
        Component: "istiod",
        Info:      version.BuildInfo{Version:"1.13.2", GitRevision:"91533d04e894ff86b80acd6d7a4517b144f9e19a", GolangVersion:"", BuildStatus:"Clean", GitTag:"1.13.2"},
    },
}

Revision 1-14-1:
&version.MeshInfo{
    {
        Component: "istiod",
        Info:      version.BuildInfo{Version:"1.14.1", GitRevision:"f59ce19ec6b63bbb70a65c43ac423845f1129464", GolangVersion:"", BuildStatus:"Clean", GitTag:"1.14.1"},
    },
    {
        Component: "istiod",
        Info:      version.BuildInfo{Version:"1.14.1", GitRevision:"f59ce19ec6b63bbb70a65c43ac423845f1129464", GolangVersion:"", BuildStatus:"Clean", GitTag:"1.14.1"},

issue.title: Problem with Service with MetalLB loadbalancerIP

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

Hello all,

I am sorry for the format, I started by trying to open a discussion on _[discuss.istio.io](discuss.istio.io)_, but the site seems to be abandonned but by pill manufacturers.


We activated istio in our lab in PERMISSIVE mode and a few services broke.  One of them is a loadbalancer for mariadb servers that live outside of kubernetes.  The loadbalancers live in pods and the service fronting them is using a LoadbalancerIP obtained through MetalLB.  


In schema that follow, the Mariadb servers live in vms.  Before injection with with the side car, everything worked just fine.  Connexion path 1,2, 3 and 4 worked juste fine.


Once side-car injection has happened, a few connexions stoped working.
![With Istio](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1424864/180006259-bd5784ec-d6c8-4bf1-84c4-e9c60ec3cc53.png)


That is, connexion 1 and 3 that try to talk to the LoadBalancerIP (which is obviously not a clusterIP) do not work.  It obviously has to do with the server [side protocol](https://istio.io/latest/docs/ops/deployment/requirements/#server-first-protocols) that is mysql.  I have modified the service in the `infra-lb` namespace to tag correctly the service with either or both `appProtocol` field or to make sure the name respects `name: <protocol>[-<suffix>]` syntax.

To no avail.  The behaviour is still different between the two IPs.  By the ways, CentOS-tools is simply a centos image with lots of tools that we have in each of our kubernetes clusters so we can comfortably tests things.

Notice that the CentOS-tools pod can talk directly to mariadb through connexion without any issues.

I can fix the problem for the CentOS tools image which belong to the mesh by publishing a ServiceEntry and VirtualService (in infra-lb)  for the LoadBlancerIP.  Yes, not for the mariadb Server, but for the service.

```yaml
piVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: ServiceEntry
metadata:
  name: mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio
spec:
  hosts:
  - mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio.interne.lab.montreal.ca # not used
  addresses:
  - 10.224.3.102 # LoadBlancer VIPs obtained through MetallLB
  ports:
  - number: 3306
    #name: tcp-maria
    name: maria
    protocol: TCP
  location: MESH_EXTERNAL
  resolution: NONE
 ``` 

```yaml
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: routetcp-maria-mettallb
spec:
  hosts:
  - mariadb-metalllb-lab-istio.interne.lab.montreal.ca
  tcp:
  - match:
    - port: 3306
    route:
    - destination:
        host: haproxy-mariadb-srv
        port:
          number: 3306
```

This will correct connexion 3.  That is, the centOS pod that belongs to the mesh will now be able to connect to mariadb using the LoadBalancerIP.  But, external connexion still do not work, connexion one for instance.

I have being able to make it work by adding a PeerAuthentication object that deactivates mTLS  altogether :

```yaml
apiVersion: security.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: PeerAuthentication
metadata:
  name: default
spec:
  mtls:
    mode: DISABLE
  # portLevelMtls:
  #   3306:
  #     mode: DISABLE
```

Notice that I cannot have `mtls` to `PERMISSIVE` and `portLevelMtls` to `DISABLE`.  It's just ignored for some reason.

Can anyone shed light on this behaviour ?  Why are there differences for cluster-ip and loadbalancer ip when coming in from the mesh.  And differences between mesh clients and outside-of-kubernetes clients on the loadbalancer-ip ?  Is it possible to have my cake and eat it too ?  That is have mTLS for mesh clients and no TLS for external clients ?  Finally, why the weird behaviour of the PeerAuthentication.

From my perspective, there should be no difference where from I enter the service on through which IP I connect to the service.


Note that the problem was there in 1.13.x and is still there in 1.14.y

### Version

```prose
istioctl version 
client version: 1.14.1
istiod version: 1.13.2
istiod version: 1.13.2
istiod version: 1.14.1
istiod version: 1.14.1
data plane version: 1.14.1 (9 proxies), 1.13.2 (83 proxies)



kubectl version --short      
Flag --short has been deprecated, and will be removed in the future. The --short output will become the default.
Client Version: v1.24.2
Kustomize Version: v4.5.4
Server Version: v1.21.5


helm version --short
v3.9.0+g7ceeda6
```


### Additional Information

istioctl bug-report

Target cluster context: simon pierre@lab

Running with the following config: 

istio-namespace: istio-system
full-secrets: false
timeout (mins): 30

issue.title: ServiceEntry-created clusters are not matched in IPv6

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

Hello everyone,
I think I found an issue with Istio 1.14.1 that is affecting connectivity to external services.
When SE are used in IPv6 to connect to external services, it seems that the requests are going into the BlackHoleCluster as they are not able to match the expected cluster.

The steps to reproduce are as follow:

0. Setup IPv6 KinD cluster or use another IPv6 cluster
1. Install Istio 1.14.1 with `istioctl install --set profile=demo --set meshConfig.outboundTrafficPolicy.mode=REGISTRY_ONLY`
2. Deploy secrets for nginx via  `kubectl create secret tls nginx-server-certs --cert=nginx.example.com.crt --key=nginx.example.com.key -n istio-system`
3. Deploy nginx configmap via `kubectl create configmap nginx-configmap --from-file=nginx.conf=nginx_http_https.conf -n istio-system`
4. Label istio-system with istio-injection=enabled using `kubectl label ns istio-system istio-injection=enabled`
5. Deploy Sleep with sidecar `kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/istio/istio/master/samples/sleep/sleep.yaml -n istio-system`
6. Deploy nginx without sidecar `kubectl apply -f nginx_http_https_no_sidecar.yaml -n istio-system`
7. Get the podIP from `kubectl get pod $NGINX_POD -n istio-system --output=yaml`
8. Replace "NGINX_IP" in se.yaml with the pod ip you retrieved earlier and apply it `kubectl apply -f se.yaml -n istio-system`.
9. From the sleep container execute `curl https://nginx.example.com --max-time 5 --resolve nginx.example.com:443:[YOUR_NGINX_IP] -k`
It will fail with SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL. 
With the help of the sidecar lgos and you can verify that it did not match the nginx cluster and therefore it went to the blackhole.
```[2022-07-06T09:00:57.041Z] "- - -" 0 UH - - "-" 0 0 13 - "-" "-" "-" "-" "-" BlackHoleCluster - [fd00:10:244::8]:443 [fd00:10:244::f]:51048 - -```
This steps does not fail on IPv4.
10. Try the same curl request from a sleep container without sidecar and everything will work as expected.


I'm attaching the resources needed to execute the aforementioned steps [resources.zip](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/9053374/resources.zip)

### Version

```prose
Istioctl:
client version: 1.14.1
control plane version: 1.14.1
data plane version: 1.14.1 (3 proxies)

Kubectl:
Client Version: v1.20.1
Server Version: v1.21.1
```


### Additional Information

[bug-report.tar.gz](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/9053341/bug-report.tar.gz)

Hello everyone,
I think I found an issue with Istio 1.14.1 that is affecting connectivity to external services.
When SE are used in IPv6 to connect to external services, it seems that the requests are going into the BlackHoleCluster as they are not able to match the expected cluster.

The steps to reproduce are as follow:

0. Setup IPv6 KinD cluster or use another IPv6 cluster
1. Install Istio 1.14.1 with `istioctl install --set profile=demo --set meshConfig.outboundTrafficPolicy.mode=REGISTRY_ONLY`
2. Deploy secrets for nginx via  `kubectl create secret tls nginx-server-certs --cert=nginx.example.com.crt --key=nginx.example.com.key -n istio-system`
3. Deploy nginx configmap via `kubectl create configmap nginx-configmap --from-file=nginx.conf=nginx_http_https.conf -n istio-system`
4. Label istio-system with istio-injection=enabled using `kubectl label ns istio-system istio-injection=enabled`
5. Deploy Sleep with sidecar `kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/istio/istio/master/samples/sleep/sleep.yaml -n istio-system`
6. Deploy nginx without sidecar `kubectl apply -f nginx_http_https_no_sidecar.yaml -n istio-system`
7. Get the podIP from `kubectl get pod $NGINX_POD -n istio-system --output=yaml`
8. Replace "NGINX_IP" in se.yaml with the pod ip you retrieved earlier and apply it `kubectl apply -f se.yaml -n istio-system`.
9. From the sleep container execute `curl https://nginx.example.com --max-time 5 --resolve nginx.example.com:443:[YOUR_NGINX_IP] -k`
It will fail with SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL. 
With the help of the sidecar lgos and you can verify that it did not match the nginx cluster and therefore it went to the blackhole.
```[2022-07-06T09:00:57.041Z] "- - -" 0 UH - - "-" 0 0 13 - "-" "-" "-" "-" "-" BlackHoleCluster - [fd00:10:244::8]:443 [fd00:10:244::f]:51048 - -```
This steps does not fail on IPv4.
10. Try the same curl request from a sleep container without sidecar and everything will work as expected.


I'm attaching the resources needed to execute the aforementioned steps [resources.zip](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/9053374/resources.zip)

### Version

```prose
Istioctl:
client version: 1.14.1
control plane version: 1.14.1
data plane version: 1.14.1 (3 proxies)

Kubectl:
Client Version: v1.20.1
Server Version: v1.21.1
```


### Additional Information

[bug-report.tar.gz](https://github.com/istio/istio/files/9053341/bug-report.tar.gz)

issue.title: Access to revisions of an external control plane

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

labels.name: lifecycle/automatically-closed
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue that has been closed automatically.

issue.body:
**Describe the feature request**

When using an [external control plane](http://localhost:1313/latest/docs/setup/additional-setup/external-controlplane/), the remote istiod location is configured in several places, three of which (`discoveryAddress`, `caAddress`, and `injectionURL`) should, but currently do not, take revisions into account:

```
spec:
  meshConfig:
    defaultConfig:
      discoveryAddress: $EXTERNAL_ISTIOD_ADDR:15012
  values:
    global:
      caAddress: $EXTERNAL_ISTIOD_ADDR:15012
    istiodRemote:
      injectionURL: https://$EXTERNAL_ISTIOD_ADDR:15017/inject
```

For example, when the the `injectionURL` value is set, it will be used in the MutatingWebhookConfiguration as is, with [no regard to the webhooks associated revision](https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/f6502508b04c38f9678c300821dd54e439b832ed/manifests/charts/istiod-remote/templates/mutatingwebhook.yaml#L8). Only the not-set (`{{- else }}`) uses the revision to select the correct istiod service.

If instead, we added a new variable (`istiodRemote.istiodURL`), we could pass the revision as a path prefix, which the external control plane could use to access the appropriate istiod revision:

```
    {{- if .Values.istiodRemote.injectionURL }}
    url: {{ .Values.istiodRemote.injectionURL }}
    {{- else if .Values.istiodRemote.istiodURL }}
    url: {{ .Values.istiodRemote.istiodURL }}:15017{{- if not (eq .Values.revision "") }}/{{ .Values.revision }}{{- end }}/inject
    {{- else }}
    service:
      name: istiod{{- if not (eq .Values.revision "") }}-{{ .Values.revision }}{{- end }}
      namespace: {{ .Release.Namespace }}
      path: "/inject"
    {{- end }}
```

If we make a similar change for all three variables, this would also simplify the external control plane configuration. Only one variable (`istiodRemote.istiodURL`) would need to be configured, instead of the current three:

```
spec:
  values:
    istiodRemote:
      istiodURL: https://$EXTERNAL_ISTIOD_ADDR
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**


[ ] Docs
[x] Installation
[ ] Networking
[ ] Performance and Scalability
[ ] Extensions and Telemetry
[ ] Security
[ ] Test and Release
[x] User Experience
[ ] Developer Infrastructure



**Additional context**

issue.title: Rotate test-infra-trusted build cluster kubeconfig
issue.body:
The test-infra-trusted cluster root CA is expiring soon, which will need to be rotated, and the old kubeconfig for Prow service cluster to authenticate with this build cluster will be invalid after the rotation. So a new kubeconfig is needed to avoid breakage of the connection to this build cluster.

Due to security reasons GKE doesn't allow long lived tokens any more, and the newly generated tokens are at most valid for 2 days, so there needs a way to rotate the token. This PR follows the strategy adopted by k8s prow

issue.title: Regression: VirtualService header-based routing is broken in istio proxyless mode

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
### Bug Description

After upgrading from istio 1.13.5 to 1.14.1, our cronjob workloads configured to run in proxyless mode (with grpc-agent sidecar) lost outbound gRPC connectivity. All requests just time out.

The following warning is repeating in istiod logs:

> 2022-07-19T17:10:12.741734Z     warn    ads     ADS:RDS: ACK ERROR device-pinger-job-v1086-27637510-j9mrv.default-1537 InvalidArgument:error parsing "" response: resource "outbound|9000||task-queue.default.svc.cluster.local": received route is invalid: route match:{prefix:"/" case_sensitive:{value:true} headers:{name:"mdm-ce-prerelease" string_match:{exact:"true"}}} route:{cluster:"outbound|9000||policymerger-prerelease-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local" timeout:{seconds:900} request_mirror_policies:{cluster:"outbound|9000||policymerger-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local" runtime_fraction:{default_value:{numerator:100}} trace_sampled:{}} max_stream_duration:{max_stream_duration:{seconds:900}}} metadata:{filter_metadata:{key:"istio" value:{fields:{key:"config" value:{string_value:"/apis/networking.istio.io/v1alpha3/namespaces/default/virtual-service/policymerger"}}}}} decorator:{operation:"policymerger-prerelease-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local:9000/*"} has an unrecognized header matcher: &{StringMatch:exact:"true"}

The offending configuration comes from a VirtualService definition which worked previously and still works when the default sidecar with Envoy is used.

```apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: policymerger
  namespace: default
spec:
  gateways:
  - mesh
  - default/ingress-gateway
  hosts:
  - policymerger.default.svc.cluster.local
  http:
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      headers:
        mdm-ce-prerelease:
          exact: "true"
      port: 9000
      uri: {}
    - gateways:
      - default/ingress-gateway
      headers:
        mdm-ce-prerelease:
          exact: "true"
      uri: {}
    mirror:
      host: policymerger-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local
      port:
        number: 9000
    retries:
      attempts: 0
    route:
    - destination:
        host: policymerger-prerelease-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 9000
    timeout: 900s
  - match:
    - gateways:
      - mesh
      headers:
        mdm-destination:
          regex: policymerger-v1064
      port: 9000
      uri: {}
    - gateways:
      - default/ingress-gateway
      headers:
        mdm-destination:
          regex: policymerger-v1064
      uri: {}
    retries:
      attempts: 0
    route:
    - destination:
        host: policymerger-v1064.default.svc.cluster.local
        port:
          number: 9000
    timeout: 900s
```

I also tried with prefix and regex matchers but the result was the same.

### Version

```prose
$ istioctl version
client version: 1.14.1
control plane version: 1.14.1
data plane version: 1.14.1 (48 proxies)
$ kubectl version --short
Client Version: v1.23.5
Server Version: v1.23.5
```


### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: Routing to original DC after a failover hop
issue.body:
**Describe the feature request**
Routing to original DC after the failover for one hop in a Call-graph.

**Detailed:**
As per the below service graph, we like to get the RED traffic back to DC1 after ServiceB. We are looking for the ability/configurations to make the proxy at Service-B do the following:

1. Remember the source-DC(say origin-DC) of the downstream call
2. Tie/Relate the corresponding upstream calls resulting due to the downstream calls.
3. **Prefer calling the upstream systems in the origin-DC instead of local-DC.**

By default Service-B in DC2 would make all upstream calls to Service-C in the same DC i.e., DC2.


![Helios_with_Istio_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5907779/170421956-8d0df2bf-e9f6-4ea7-b5a1-44101a9a10ac.png)

**Motivation:**
Lesser capacity requirement.

With the above capability, after the ServiceB failure in DC1, only ServiceB in DC2 needs to scale-out for 100% traffic. All the upstream systems further in the chain(i.e., Service C onwards) can remain the same without having to scale-out.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Could not find a solution supporting this traffic routing requirement.

**Affected product area (please put an X in all that apply)**
None of the below. It affects the Capacity footprint.
[ ] Docs
[ ] Installation
[ ] Networking
[ ] Performance and Scalability
[ ] Extensions and Telemetry
[ ] Security
[ ] Test and Release
[ ] User Experience
[ ] Developer Infrastructure

**Affected features (please put an X in all that apply)**

[x] Multi Cluster
[ ] Virtual Machine
[ ] Multi Control Plane


**Additional context**
Currently our infrastructure is primarily in our Private DC and in the process of hybrid journey.

issue.title: Provide a way for workloads to ensure traffic has passed Istio
issue.body:
**Describe the feature request**

Istio is supposed to remove the burden from workloads implementing several infrastructural or cross-cutting aspects themselves. Among them are security features. 
Workloads can only properly trust that constraints have been imposed by Istio if there would be a way to guarantee (from a workload perspective) that traffic definitely has passed Envoy before entering. 

Multiple possibilities can lead to traffic bypassing envoy:
* Only some ports are configured to be intercepted and some are not
* (K8s-)Sidecar injection did not happen because of missing/broken webhook or missing inject annotation
* Istio-CNI might be disturbed, not configuring the interception

I'm looking for a way the application can do ne verification to then know that it can trust all it sees being handled properly. 
One such example is trusting X-Forwarded-Client-Cert headers to do fine-grained authorization based on that.
Another one is that configured AuthorizationPolicies have been processed.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

* Originally, binding an application to localhost was one way to ensure envoy was involved, but this is deprecated (https://github.com/istio/istio/issues/37642)
* Adding outside monitoring to ensure a sidecar is attached only goes half way, broken Istio-CNI would not be noticed with this
* An EnvoyFilter might do the trick with adding a signature, but the signing secret must be handled secretly (I didn't dive deeper into this option so far)

**Affected product area (please put an X in all that apply)**

[ ] Docs
[ ] Installation
[ ] Networking
[ ] Performance and Scalability
[ ] Extensions and Telemetry
[X] Security
[ ] Test and Release
[ ] User Experience
[ ] Developer Infrastructure

**Affected features (please put an X in all that apply)**

[ ] Multi Cluster
[ ] Virtual Machine
[ ] Multi Control Plane

**Additional context**

issue.title: CNI logging issues

labels.name: area/networking/cni
labels.description: Istio CNI-related issues

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
CNI logging works by sending logs over a UDS socket from the istio-cni binary up to the user-space install-cni container. There are a few issues here around logging levels and scopes.

* https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/764e6688921e326bdaa530d5ef3a9ed5d87372f7/cni/pkg/plugin/plugin.go#L177 sets the scope as configured by `logLevel` in the configmap, which is `Values.cni.logLevel`. This only handles default scope. if we have other scopes, we cannot configure them. Either we should apply this to all scopes, or allow the standard parsing of scopes that log_output_level does
* Daemonset doesn't allow setting the level at all: https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/ff3ccd19943796e58e9ac16db114a99dcaa8b4d6/manifests/charts/istio-cni/templates/daemonset.yaml#L76
* Maybe not a bug, but something we should consider: https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/bf2adb0be5c057924a79d1a78a39ffb87aeb1175/cni/pkg/log/uds.go#L121 loses the original `scope` of the log. If we send scoped logs, we lose that info. Either we can lookup the original scope, or we should add a key to do the equivalent

issue.title: CNI logging issues

labels.name: area/networking/cni
labels.description: Istio CNI-related issues

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Indicates a PR or issue hasn't been manipulated by an Istio team member for a while

issue.body:
CNI logging works by sending logs over a UDS socket from the istio-cni binary up to the user-space install-cni container. There are a few issues here around logging levels and scopes.

* https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/764e6688921e326bdaa530d5ef3a9ed5d87372f7/cni/pkg/plugin/plugin.go#L177 sets the scope as configured by `logLevel` in the configmap, which is `Values.cni.logLevel`. This only handles default scope. if we have other scopes, we cannot configure them. Either we should apply this to all scopes, or allow the standard parsing of scopes that log_output_level does
* Daemonset doesn't allow setting the level at all: https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/ff3ccd19943796e58e9ac16db114a99dcaa8b4d6/manifests/charts/istio-cni/templates/daemonset.yaml#L76
* Maybe not a bug, but something we should consider: https://github.com/istio/istio/blob/bf2adb0be5c057924a79d1a78a39ffb87aeb1175/cni/pkg/log/uds.go#L121 loses the original `scope` of the log. If we send scoped logs, we lose that info. Either we can lookup the original scope, or we should add a key to do the equivalent

issue.title: Soft multi-tenancy on istio 1.14.3
issue.body:
### Bug Description

We are building Multi-Tenant EKS cluster where there is a need to create service mesh control plane for the tenant namespace/namespaces.

Looks like appNamespace argument is no longer present in pilot discovery. How can we limit the controller to limit monitoring to specific namespaces?

Is there any cluster plane topology on istio 1.14.3 that support multi-tenancy on same kubernetes cluster.   We trying to see something like maistra/service mesh operator offered on OpenShift where multiple control planes can be mapped to application namespace using servicemesh member roll. 

https://istio.io/latest/blog/2018/soft-multitenancy/#:~:text=For%20this%20blog%2C%20%E2%80%9Csoft%20multi,and%20one%20mesh%20per%20tenant.

issue.title: Egress TLS origination: Modify the role to allow only TLS certificate secret access
issue.body:
The role definition in the documentation suggests allowing a pod to read all the secrets in the namespaces and this is violating the least privilege principle.

It is possible to allow access only to the secret containing the TLS certificate and it is confirmed that with this narrow role, the sidecar proxy is still able to access the secret.

issue.title: Place `istio.metadata_exchange` before RBAC filters for network and HTTP filters

labels.name: size/M
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: release-notes-none
labels.description: Indicates a PR that does not require release notes.

issue.body:
**Please provide a description of this PR:**
Fixes #41066 
In istio 1.12, RBAC filter shows up before metadata exchange filter for both network and HTTP (subfilters of `http_connection_manager`) filters. This was preventing the metadata to be populated for requests that were denied (403 in case of HTTP or dial failed for TCP) in OAP access logs. This PR fixes the order by putting RBAC filter(both network and http) before `istio.metadata_exchange` filter while generating network or http filters.

This exists even in istio 1.15 and will need a separate fix because a lot of code changed around plugins between 1.12 and 1.15.

ef-header-to-metadata-response_rules.yaml

kubectl apply -f ef-header-to-metadata-response_rules.yaml -n istio-system

```
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: header-to-metadata 
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      istio: ingressgateway
  configPatches:
  - applyTo: HTTP_FILTER
    match:
      context: GATEWAY
      listener:
        portNumber: 8080
        filterChain:
          filter:
            name: "envoy.filters.network.http_connection_manager"
            subFilter:
              name: "envoy.filters.http.router"
    patch:
      operation: INSERT_FIRST
      value: 
        name: envoy.filters.http.header_to_metadata
        typed_config:
          "@type": type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.header_to_metadata.v3.Config
          response_rules:
            - header: x-version
              on_header_present:
                metadata_namespace: envoy.lb
                key: version
                type: STRING
              on_header_missing:
                metadata_namespace: envoy.lb
                key: default
                value: 'true'
                type: STRING
              remove: false
```

```

kind: EnvoyFilter
metadata:
  name: rbac
spec:
  workloadSelector:
    labels:
      istio: ingressgateway
  priority: 20
  configPatches:
  - applyTo: HTTP_FILTER
    match:
      context: GATEWAY
      listener:
        portNumber: 8080
        filterChain:
          filter:
            name: "envoy.filters.network.http_connection_manager"
            subFilter:
              name: "envoy.filters.http.router"
    patch:
      operation: INSERT_BEFORE
      value:         
          name: envoy.filters.http.rbac
          typedConfig:
            '@type': type.googleapis.com/envoy.extensions.filters.http.rbac.v3.RBAC
            rules:
              action: DENY
              policies:
                "product-viewer":
                  permissions:
                  - metadata:
                      filter: envoy.lb
                      path:
                      - key: default
                      value: 
                        string_match:
                          exact: "true"
                  principals:
                  - any: true
